abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Programmatic
            Finance and Growth Development Policy Loan Project for
            Mexico were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: country
            ownership drives the partnership, while the quality of the
            underpinning technical analysis is key to the relationship.
            Mexico's sophistication and good internal consultation
            process imply a well defined client agenda, which can be
            backed by the provision of technical expertise by the Bank,
            taking advantage strong cross country experience.
            Flexibility with Middle Income Countries (MICs) implies
            ongoing dialogue and room for better responsiveness in
            planning and execution. Irrespective of political economy
            considerations (that were important in this operation's
            instrument choice), a broad reform programmatic approach can
            provide for ongoing dialogue on a number of policy fronts
            and more flexibility in responding to MICs changing needs
            and priorities. Broad reform based Development Policy Loans
            (DPLs) can benefit in terms of supervision cost by taking
            advantage of the sector's overall dialogue and lending/
            non lending program. Intrinsic differences can sometime
            explain the slow take up of capital markets for funding.
